topic.title: the EU is FUCKING us
topic.body:
few things that i noticed

- GDPR
- Article 13
- End of the 500 € note
- Buying and Selling cryptocurrency becomes more and more difficult
- The limit for anonymous precious metals purchases has been lowered drastically in almost every EU country
- Additional fee for cash payments is being considered
- You need verify yourself with a picture of your face and your ID in order to get a phone number
- Fingerprints will become mandatory in ID cards

1566448853_12XcKUGvjkDZ5ufLFESyYLYXgELag.body:
Precious metals and crypto are both way better options than governments toilet paper money.

Precious metals are a better store of value but only if you have a good hiding place and no plans to move in the near future.

For transferring value into another country of course crypto is the better choice. Also you don't have much risk of buying counterfeit cryptos unlike with precious metals.

> [xcape2net](#comment_345_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): If 47 people each create their own version of bitcoin with the exact same algorithms as bit coin, call them bitcoin1 through bitcoin47, how will you decide which one to invest in?  If you decide to invest in bitcoin27 and I decide to invest in bitcoin5, neither of us will be investing in the original bitcoin.  That is inflation, just the same as if we were talking about dollars or marks or yen.  There is a finite investment pool being spread over more investment units.

the majority of people would invest in the original bitcoin not in bitcoin27, bitcoin47

The original Bitcoin is mostly considered as "digital gold" and i don't think that this will change anytime soon. I cannot predict the future but i think perhaps 5-10 crypto currencies will survive.

BTC dominance is 68,4% on Coinmarketcap

> [xcape2net](#comment_349_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): Why do you think that?  Where did you get the number 68.4%?

https://coinmarketcap.com

> [xcape2net](#comment_349_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): Why do you think that?  I remember seeing 51% somewhere recently, but that may have been earlier this year when the price of bitcoin was down.

It looks like that to me. Bitcoin, Ethereum, Monero and a few other cryptos will survive.

> [xcape2net](#comment_351_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): I've given what I think are very good reasons for thinking no cryptocurrency will survive over the long term.  I've not heard good reasons for why you think they will.  I'm open-minded and willing to listen to anyone who can refute my arguments based on something other than feelings and wishes.  Believe me, I would love to have some form of currency that could replace the thoroughly corrupt system we have in place today.  I would love for cryptocurrencies to be the solution.  But, given the arguments that I've made against cryptocurrencies, I just don't see that they are capable of doing that.  Depending on public perceptions of cryptocurrencies, they could survive for another 10 years, perhaps another 100 years, but eventually they are doomed to fail (at least as a store of value), because they are incompatible with the fundamental economic principle of supply and demand.
